title: TriggerKit
text:
This system allows you to:

Define Snowflake views to monitor
Schedule when to check these views for new data
Configure actions to trigger when data is available
Extend with custom actions for your specific needs



Install latest from the GitHub repository:
$ pip install git+https://github.com/Datatistics/triggerkit.git
or from pypi
$ pip install triggerkit

title: TriggerKit
text:
Usage
Run the system with your configuration file:
# Using default config.toml in current directory
snowflake-actions

# Or specify a config file
snowflake-actions --config /path/to/your/config.toml

# To check your configuration file syntax
snowflake-actions --check-config

# To list available actions
snowflake-actions --list-actions

# For verbose logging
snowflake-actions --verbose

title: TriggerKit
text:
Creating Custom Actions
You can extend the system with your own custom actions:
import triggerkit as tk

@tk.register("my_custom_action", "Description of what this action does")
def my_custom_action(data: List[Dict]):
    """
    Takes in records from Snowflake view and processes them how you want.
    
    Args:
        data: List of records from Snowflake
        
    Returns:
        Dictionary with action results
    """
    # Your custom logic here
    return {"processed": len(data)}

title: TriggerKit
text:
Environment Variables

CONFIG_PATH: Path to the TOML configuration file
SNOWFLAKE_PASSWORD: Snowflake password (recommended over storing in config)
LOG_LEVEL: Set the logging level (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)

title: TriggerKit
text:
Built-in Actions
The system comes with several built-in actions:

send_alert: Sends email and Slack notifications
log_incident: Records incidents in a tracking system
generate_report: Creates summary reports from data

title: actions
text:
When your views yields results, what TriggerKit performs are actions. These are functions that take in results and perform things like send slack messages, perform SQL operations, make API calls, etc.
You can either use some of our built-in actions or build your own!

text:

init

*Initialize the application.
Args: config_path: Path to TOML config file
Returns: None*

#exporti

def main(args=None):
    """Main entry point for the application.
    
    Args:
        args: Optional list of command line argument strings, or parsed args object.
              If None, will parse from command line.
    """
    if args is None or not isinstance(args, argparse.Namespace):
        args = _parse_arguments(args)
    
    # Set log level based on verbosity
    if args.verbose:
        logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
        logger.debug("Verbose logging enabled")
    
    # Check if config file exists
    config_path = Path(args.config)
    if not config_path.exists():
        logger.error(f"Configuration file not found: {config_path}")
        sys.exit(1)
    
    logger.info(f"Using configuration file: {config_path}")
    
    # Just list actions if requested
    if args.list_actions:
        list_available_actions()
        sys.exit(0)
    
    # Just check config if requested
    if args.check_config:
        try:
            config = core.load_config(args.config)
            logger.info(f"Configuration file is valid: {args.config}")
            
            # Display summary of configuration
            logger.info(f"Found {len(config.get('views', []))} views")
            logger.info(f"Found {len(config.get('jobs', []))} jobs")
            
            # Display enabled jobs
            enabled_jobs = [j for j in config.get('jobs', []) if j.get('enabled', True)]
            logger.info(f"Enabled jobs ({len(enabled_jobs)}):")
            for job in enabled_jobs:
                logger.info(f"  - {job.get('name')}: {job.get('view')} â†’ {job.get('actions')} ({job.get('schedule')})")
            
            sys.exit(0)
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error validating configuration: {str(e)}")
            sys.exit(1)
    
    # Initialize and run the application
    try:
        logger.info("Starting Snowflake Action System")
        init_app(args.config)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        logger.info("Shutting down Snowflake Action System")
    except Exception as e:
        logger.error(f"Application error: {str(e)}", exc_info=True)
        sys.exit(1)

Making Your Own!
It is simple to make your own actions. All you have to do is make a function that takes in a List of Dicts (List[Dict]) and register it with the system

source

register

*Register your function as an action in the global registry.
Args:
â€¢ name: Unique identifier for the action
â€¢ description: Optional description of what the action does
Raises:

Using register is simple! All you have to do is import the triggerkit package and call register as a decorator:
import triggerkit as tk

def my_function(data: List[Dict]):
    """
    Takes in records from Snowflake view and processes them how you want.
    
    Args:

    """
    # Your custom logic here
